short_overview.initial_text: The [animal name] is a [type of animal] native to [broad region]. It is known for [Key distinctive feature].

short_overview.description: Template for creating a concise opening paragraph for animal articles

sentence_1_definition.template: The {animal_common_name} or {alternative_name} is a {taxonomic_classification} native to {geographic_range}.

animal_common_name.validation: Must be lowercase unless proper noun
animal_common_name.help_text: Use the most widely recognized common name

alternative_name.validation: Must be lowercase unless proper noun
alternative_name.help_text: Include the most common alternative name if one exists

taxonomic_classification.placeholder: e.g., population of the tiger subspecies Panthera tigris tigris
taxonomic_classification.validation: Must include scientific name in italics
taxonomic_classification.help_text: Specify if it's a species, subspecies, or population
taxonomic_classification.source_guidance: Use IUCN, Mammal Species of the World, or Cat Specialist Group

geographic_range.placeholder: e.g., Northeast China, the Russian Far East, and possibly North Korea
geographic_range.help_text: Where does this animal currently live?
geographic_range.source_guidance: Use recent range maps or distribution studies

sentence_1_definition.example: The Siberian tiger or Amur tiger is a population of the tiger subspecies Panthera tigris tigris native to Northeast China, the Russian Far East, and possibly North Korea.

key_distinctive_feature_1.placeholder: e.g., its thick fur adapted to cold climates
key_distinctive_feature_1.validation: Should be a notable physical or behavioral trait
key_distinctive_feature_1.help_text: What makes this animal unique or recognizable?
key_distinctive_feature_1.source_guidance: Use peer-reviewed studies on morphology or behavior

key_distinctive_feature_2.placeholder: e.g., being one of the largest tiger populations

sentence_2_distinctive_features.example: It is known for its thick, pale golden coat and being one of the largest tiger subspecies.

sentence_3_conservation_status.template: The species is classified as {conservation_status} by the IUCN, with an estimated population of {current_population} in the wild as of {year}.

conservation_status.help_text: Select the current IUCN Red List status
conservation_status.source_guidance: Must cite IUCN Red List directly

current_population.validation: Include range if exact number unknown
current_population.source_guidance: Use census data or peer-reviewed population studies

sentence_3_conservation_status.example: The species is classified as Endangered by the IUCN, with an estimated population of approximately 500-600 individuals in the wild as of 2022.

short_overview.complete_example: The Siberian tiger or Amur tiger is a population of the tiger subspecies Panthera tigris tigris native to Northeast China, the Russian Far East, and possibly North Korea. It is known for its thick, pale golden coat adapted to harsh winters and being one of the largest tiger populations. The species is classified as Endangered by the IUCN, with an estimated population of approximately 500-600 individuals in the wild as of 2022.
suggested_source_types: Geographic distribution study or range map

taxonomy_in_brief.description: Template for summarizing taxonomic classification and evolutionary relationships

sentence_1_higher_classification.template: The {animal_common_name} belongs to the {taxonomic_family} family within the order {taxonomic_order}.

animal_common_name.help_text: Same as used in short overview

taxonomic_family.source_guidance: Use Mammal Species of the World or ITIS

sentence_1_higher_classification.example: The Siberian tiger belongs to the Felidae family within the order Carnivora.

sentence_2_scientific_name.template: It is scientifically classified as {full_scientific_name}, first described by {original_describer} in {year_described}.

full_scientific_name.validation: Must be in italics, genus capitalized
full_scientific_name.source_guidance: Use original taxonomic description or authoritative revision

original_describer.help_text: Who first scientifically described this animal?

sentence_2_scientific_name.example: It is scientifically classified as Panthera tigris altaica, first described by Temminck in 1844.

evolutionary_relationship.placeholder: e.g., it is genetically close to the extinct Caspian tiger
evolutionary_relationship.validation: Should reference phylogenetic or genetic findings

sentence_3_evolutionary_note.example: Recent genetic studies indicate it is genetically close to the extinct Caspian tiger, with which it shared a common ancestor approximately 10,000 years ago.

taxonomy_in_brief.complete_example: The Siberian tiger belongs to the Felidae family within the order Carnivora. It is scientifically classified as Panthera tigris altaica, first described by Temminck in 1844. Recent genetic studies indicate it is genetically close to the extinct Caspian tiger, with which it shared a common ancestor approximately 10,000 years ago.
suggested_source_types: Taxonomic authority database (ITIS, Catalogue of Life)

content.general_description: The tiger is reddish-rusty, or rusty-yellow in colour, with narrow black transverse stripes. The body length is not less than 150 cm, condylobasal length of skull 250 mm, zygomatic width 180 mm, and length of upper carnassial tooth over 26 mm long. It has an extended supple body standing on rather short legs with a fairly long tail.

skull.characteristics: Large size, very powerful facial region, very broad in the region of the canines
skull.skull_prominences: Sagittal crest and crista occipitalis very high and strong in old males, often more massive than Bengal tigers
skull.sexual_dimorphism: Female skull always smaller and never as heavily built as male

fur_and_coat.whiskers_and_hair: Whiskers and hair on back of head and top of neck greatly elongated
fur_and_coat.winter_coat: Generally less bright and rusty compared to summer coat
fur_and_coat.stripe_appearance: Winter stripes appear broader with less defined outlines due to longer fur

siberian_tiger_characteristics.notes: Data includes historical comparisons showing that contemporary Siberian tigers are lighter than historical ones, possibly due to reduced prey abundance from illegal hunting and capturing of sick/injured individuals in conflict situations.
